io.netty.handler.codec

Class ByteToByteCodec

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.netty.channel.ChannelHandlerAdapter
      • io.netty.channel.ChannelStateHandlerAdapter
        • io.netty.channel.ChannelDuplexHandler
          • io.netty.handler.codec.ByteToByteCodec
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelHandler, ChannelInboundByteHandler, ChannelOperationHandler, ChannelOutboundByteHandler, ChannelStateHandler

    public abstract class ByteToByteCodec
extends ChannelDuplexHandler
implements ChannelInboundByteHandler, ChannelOutboundByteHandler
    A Codec for on-the-fly encoding/decoding of bytes. This can be thought of as a combination of ByteToByteDecoder and ByteToByteEncoder. Here is an example of a ByteToByteCodec which just square Integer read from a ByteBuf. 
         public class SquareCodec extends ByteToByteCodec {
         @Override
         public void decode(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ByteBuf in, ByteBuf out)
                 throws Exception {
             if (in.readableBytes() < 4) {
                 return;
             }
             int value = in.readInt();
             out.writeInt(value * value);
         }

         @Overrride
         public void encode(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ByteBuf in, ByteBuf out)
                 throws Exception {
             if (in.readableBytes() < 4) {
                 return;
             }
             int value = in.readInt();
             out.writeInt(value / value);
         }
     }

    • Method Detail

      • newInboundBuffer

        public ByteBuf newInboundBuffer(ChannelHandlerContext ctx)
                         throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelInboundByteHandler
        Returns a new buffer which will be used to consume inbound data for the given ChannelHandlerContext.

        Please note that this method can be called from any thread repeatatively, and thus you should neither perform stateful operation nor keep the reference of the created buffer as a member variable. Get it always using ChannelHandlerContext.inboundByteBuffer() or ChannelHandlerContext.inboundMessageBuffer().

        An implementation should respect the ChannelConfig.getDefaultHandlerByteBufType() setting unless there's a good reason to ignore it. If in doubt, use ChannelHandlerUtil.allocate(ChannelHandlerContext).

        Specified by:
        newInboundBuffer in interface ChannelInboundByteHandler
        Throws:
        Exception

      • inboundBufferUpdated

        public void inboundBufferUpdated(ChannelHandlerContext ctx)
                          throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelStateHandler
        The inbound buffer of the ChannelHandlerContext was updated with new data. This means something may be ready to get processed by the actual ChannelStateHandler implementation. It's up to the implementation to consume it or keep it in the buffer to wait for more data and consume it later.
        Specified by:
        inboundBufferUpdated in interface ChannelStateHandler
        Throws:
        Exception

      • newOutboundBuffer

        public ByteBuf newOutboundBuffer(ChannelHandlerContext ctx)
                          throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelOutboundByteHandler
        Returns a new buffer which will be used to transfer outbound data for the given ChannelHandlerContext.

        Please note that this method can be called from any thread repeatatively, and thus you should neither perform stateful operation nor keep the reference of the created buffer as a member variable. Get it always using ChannelHandlerContext.outboundByteBuffer() or ChannelHandlerContext.outboundMessageBuffer().

        An implementation should respect the ChannelConfig.getDefaultHandlerByteBufType() setting unless there's a good reason to ignore it. If in doubt, use ChannelHandlerUtil.allocate(ChannelHandlerContext).

        Specified by:
        newOutboundBuffer in interface ChannelOutboundByteHandler
        Throws:
        Exception

      • discardInboundReadBytes

        public void discardInboundReadBytes(ChannelHandlerContext ctx)
                             throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelInboundByteHandler
        Discards the read bytes of the inbound buffer and optionally trims its unused portion to reduce memory consumption. The most common implementation of this method will look like the following: 
             ctx.inboundByteBuffer().discardSomeReadBytes();
        Specified by:
        discardInboundReadBytes in interface ChannelInboundByteHandler
        Throws:
        Exception

        Description copied from interface: ChannelOutboundByteHandler

             ctx.outboundByteBuffer().discardSomeReadBytes();
        Specified by:
        discardOutboundReadBytes in interface ChannelOutboundByteHandler
